Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RNMS: Kinetic Description of Emerging Challenges in Multiscale Problems of Natural Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a Research Network in Mathematical Sciences: ?Kinetic description of emerging challenges in multiscale problems of natural sciences? (KI-net). Kinetic descriptions have traditionally played a central role in many areas of mathematical physics. In the last two decades, however, kinetic descriptions have emerged as an indispensable tool for a quantitative description of diverse phenomena, ranging from semi-conductors, polymers and plasma, to cell migrations, swarming, and neuron networks, as well as traffic, social and economic networking. It is in this context that the KI-net will foster cross-fertilization between mathematics and other scientific disciplines, with particular focus on the following three areas:
* Quantum dynamics with applications to chemistry;
* Network dynamics with applications to social sciences; and
* Kinetic models of biological processes.

The principal objectives are to foster new kinetic-based national and international collaborations; to train a future generation of researchers to address new challenges, and to sustain the United-States? leading role on the international stage in this field. The proposed KI-net will bring the full range of mathematical techniques to bear on important scientific challenges in kinetic descriptions of new phenomena in physical, biological and social sciences. The ultimate goal is the development, analysis and computation of novel kinetic descriptions with various applications in these disciplines. KI-net will offer a unique platform to carry out these objectives. It will be centered around three hubs: the Center for Scientific Computation & Math Modeling (CSCAMM) in the University of Maryland, the Institute for Computational and Engineering Science (ICES) at UT Austin, and the Department of Mathematics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. At the initial stage, they will inter-connect 12 nodes through a series of edges, involving 25 core participants.

KI-net Research Network home page: http://www2.cscamm.umd.edu/ki-net/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For seven years the the UT Austin Hub of the RNMS on ?Kinetic description of emerging challenges in multi-scale problems of natural sciences?, with its nodes at Arizona State University at Pheonix, California State University at Northridge, University of California at los Angeles, Los Alamos National Laboratory and Stanford University generated a strong level of activities engaging the PIs and Ki-Net associates has been developed through the opportunities of this research Networkthat have involved at 195 funded participants in the last 7 years.

Suche activities keep on increasing and developed new reserach groups leaving a lost lasting legacy of the 'Ki-Net' project, as the PIs at the three Hubs, UM at College Park, UW at Madison and UT Austin, call it.

The UT Austin Hub and its paticipant Nodes have produced more than 150 collaborative publications since 2012, of which almost 90 are reported from the ASU-Node and the UT-Austin Hub alone.

All past activities and publications regarding the network are posted at the KI-Net website maintained at the University of Maryland Hub http://www.ki-net.umd.edu/

Since 2012, there have been 209 posted activities sponsored at UT Austin Hub that funded to total of about 351 participants, of which 79 are female individuals. Detailed information about these funded activities and publications can be found at https://www.ki-net.umd.edu/db/admin/units/

The funding effort returned a strong level of activities engaging the PIs and Ki-Net associates who enhanced their skills through the opportunities of this research network and activities. The research group has been quite broad and diverse. The network brought in a very strong engagement of junior people at the graduate Student and postdoctoral level on the proposal funded areas and beyond. We have achieved a highly visible level of the network activities. There planned activities that follows from the funded 2012-2019 period have left a significant legacy about the Kinetic transport theory community under a very broad unbrella.

The impact of these projects have enhanced the participation of Junior and Senior researchers in the areas of computational and analytical kinetics with applications ranging from chemistry to plasmas to social network kinetic flow modeling in whithin the research network.

In addition, network groups impacted other disciplines. The UT Austin group has strong connections on computational kinetics for the Plasma group at the Institute of Plasma Fusion at the Physics department, computational Kinetics at Aerospace Engineering and the computational Chemistry group at ICES. Graduate students were co-adviced by faculty members in these different goups. Strong interactions were being developed with Industrial partners, such as the  ASU group with Intel researchers. The Stanford Group, who has very strong connections with Stanford University Statistics and Computer Sciences groups, haev developed new techniques applied to Machine and Deep learning, and have become consultors for AI and IT companies in the Palo Alto/Menlo Park areas in California.  The Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) group has extablished strong interaction with the UT Austin group as well as the Oak Ridge National Labratory (ORNL) ones.

New analytical and computational techniques have been developed for kinetic transport modeling. More specifically, the network focus on the development deterministic techniques that can compete with classical stochastically design MonteCarlo solvers. These alternative methods are known to perform better on strong transient regimes. These are tools of strong impact to the further development of Natural and Social Science, Engineering and technology. Many of these projects have created a strong junior group of scientific computing individuals who are computational codes developers. A significant part of their computational codes are being shared and some parts of their pseudo codes are publicly available through publications.

The work on analytical and computational collisional plasmas impact a wide range of areas ranging from computational chemistry, to the semiconductor industry, to the design strategy of cold fusion energy as well.

These projects have created a strong junior group of scientific computing individuals who are computational codes developers. A significant part of their computational codes are shared and some parts of their pseudo codes are publicly available through publications.

Overall, the collaborative research effort  funded by the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences titled "Kinetic Description of Emerging Challenges in Multiscale Problems of Natural Sciences" has created new scientific  studies and products that will carry a strong long lasting impact, nationally and internationally. 


Last Modified: 09/12/2019
Modified by: Irene M Gamba
